page.addressleaf:
fol.107v
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasuro
r
of England.
3 Julij
1591
. M
r
Bodeleie to my L/.
3 June 91
]
fol.106r
May it please yo
r
good L. because I stande
in some doubt, whether
e answear of
e states
for their course of navigation will be sent
directly from themselves or exhibited heere
to me, to be conveied to her
Ma
tie
I thought it
expedient to send yo
r
L. heerew
t
e transcript
of suche pointes, as I proposed unto them
the 2
of June, and they required then in writing,
as they are commonly accustomed in maters of
any moment. For I reserved it hitherto, thinking
to have sent it, together w
t
their answear.
We have freshe intelligence from
e campe,
that after 30 canon shotte,
e sconce of
Lever-
bert
, or
Letterbert
, hath yelded unto us, with
like conditions as
Upslacke
and
Emmentel
,
of w
ch
in my former I advertised yo
r
L.
The campe is yet remaining w
t
in 5 English
miles of
e towne of
Groeninghen
, where
Verdugo
w
t
his forces doth keepe very stronge.
Howbeit it is thought we might beate him from
thens, were it not feared in that case, that
e
towne of Groninghen being pressed, would re-
ceave him w
t
a garrison, w
ch
would be worse
for o
r
purpose, then it is as this present.
Wherupon it is supposed,
at as it hath bin re-
solved, and I have certified yo
r
L.
e Army
will come forward, to
e siege of
steenwicke
.
The greatest part of
Parmaes
forces,
and he himself, as
e bruite goeth heere, is still
about
Mariembom
and
Rees,
but we can not yet
conjecture at his further intent.
And so at this
present I take my humble leave. From
Julij/.
Leewarden. June 3 1591.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
